title.narrative: Corridors and Communities: Conserving Vital Forest Habitat N. Honduras III

description.narrative: This project will strengthen the capacity of community institutions to sustainably manage forested habitat in northern Honduras, establish a local forest protection funds, reduce anthropogenic pressure on habitat, and reforest habitat with 90,000 native trees.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: Building Honduran Capacity to restore Mangroves using Community-Based Ecological Mangrove Restoration

description.narrative: This project will build local capacity for the restoration of threatened mangrove ecosystems in the Gulf of Fonseca, Honduras by 1) training 25 Honduran conservationists in community-based ecological mangrove restoration, 2) restoring a 5 hectare demonstration site in the project area, and 3) carrying out community-based monitoring and evaluation of the restoration site.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Wildlife Without Borders-Western Hemisphere

description.narrative: This project will build local capacity for the restoration of threatened mangrove ecosystems in the Gulf of Fonseca, Honduras by 1) training 25 Honduran conservationists in community-based ecological mangrove restoration, 2) restoring a 5 hectare demonstration site in the project area, and 3) carrying out community-based monitoring and evaluation of the restoration site.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: CORRIDORS & COMMUNITIES: CONS VITAL FOREST HABITAT IN N HONDURAS IV

description.narrative: This project will strengthen the capacity of two local institutions and partner with one municipal government to conserve a total of 185,000 acres of forested habitat in and around Pico Bonito National Park (PBNP), as well as the corridor connecting PBNP with the Texiguat Wildlife Refuge and Cuero y Salado National Park in northern Honduras. These forests are critical to diverse neotropical migratory bird species. The project also involves the reforestation of 3,700 acres. Birds that will benefit include the swallow-tailed kite, peregrine falcon, Canada warbler, yellow-billed cuckoo, Kentucky warbler, cerulean warbler, and painted bunting, as well as the endemic Honduran emerald hummingbird.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: CORRIDORS & COMMUNITIES: CONS VITAL FOREST HABITAT IN N HONDURAS IV

description.narrative: The project will strengthen the capacity of local institutions to manage 75,000 hectares of forest in and around Pico Bonito National Park (PBNP) and in the corridor connecting PBNP with the Texiguat Wildlife Refuge and Cuero y Salado National Park in northern Honduras. It will also: 1) reforest 1,500 hectares with native trees; 2) establish new environmental funds for forest protection; 3) reduce anthropogenic pressure on bird habitat; 4) establish 22 ha of agroforestry plots; 5) implement silvopastoral systems on 20 ha; and 5) increase appreciation for forest habitat among the local community.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Addressing cloud forest management limitations in Volcan Pacayita Biological Reserve to conserve this threatened ecosystem and the hydrologic services it provides

description.narrative: Project will support sustainable management of cloud forests within the Pacayita Volcano Biological Reserve and reduce agricultural encroachment by 1) completing a landscape level biological assessment and threat analysis of the area, 2) evaluating water ecosystem services provided by the reserve and establishing one community agreement for the Water Ecosystem Services Compensation program, 3) convening local communities to undertake land use planning and zoning, and 4) engaging at least 10 local coffee producers on pilot projects to increase productivity and reduce their impact and expansion into the Reserve. Project activities will contribute towards the development of a management plan for the Reserve.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Addressing cloud forest management limitations in Volcan Pacayita Biological Reserve to conserve this threatened ecosystem and the hydrologic services it provides

description.narrative: Project will support sustainable management of cloud forests within the Pacayita Volcano Biological Reserve and reduce agricultural encroachment by 1) completing a landscape level biological assessment and threat analysis of the area, 2) evaluating water ecosystem services provided by the reserve and establishing one community agreement for the Water Ecosystem Services Compensation program, 3) convening local communities to undertake land use planning and zoning, and 4) engaging at least 10 local coffee producers on pilot projects to increase productivity and reduce their impact and expansion into the Reserve. Project activities will contribute towards the development of a management plan for the Reserve.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Mongabay Reporting Network: Cattle & Central American Forests

description.narrative: "Project will enable professional journalists to create a series in-depth articles - published under an open Creative Commons license that allows for re-publishing elsewhere on the intersection of cattle ranching and environmental protection in Mesoamerica. It is intended to enable high quality, detailed, and potentially investigative reporting on this subject.that may be otherwise overlooked by the media. Specific activities include: (1) development of.questions that need to be explored under this topic; (2) field proposals and commission stories.from journalists across the globe; (3) publishing ten articles on the topic in both Spanish and.English on Mongabay.com; (4) encouraging republishing in major media outlets in Central America and across the globe via the Creative Commons license. Recipient will work closely with USFWS experts and other experts selected by the USFWS to develop the list of themes and questions that need to be explored to document the scale, scope and impact of cattle production on Central Americas forests and wildlife. Those questions will then be used to seed an open call for story proposals from journalists via Mongabays various channels. USFWS will review and approve the final call for submissions before distribution. "

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Multi-organizational collaboration to integrate data and survey methods for large mammal indicator.species at the Mesoamerica regional scale

description.narrative: Project will produce Mesoamerican - wide (southern Yucatan through Panama) range and population status assessments for four large mammals likely to be impacted by anthropogenic threats in Central America jaguar (Panthera onca), white lipped peccary (Tayassu pecari), collared peccary (Pecari tajacu) and Bairds tapir (Tapirus bairdii). Specific activities include: 1) literature review to increase regional knowledge of species and identify data sources; 2) data compilation and standardization across multiple sites, with a focus on existing camera trapping data; 3) species distribution modeling to map current and future distribution patterns and identify key drivers of regional occupancy; 4) workshop in Guatemala to confirm models, train 20 participants, and develop future region-wide standardized monitoring guidelines for at least two of the focal species; and 5) dissemination of results in English and Spanish to local stakeholders, including presentation of mapping results to all protected area agencies in Central America. USFWS will suggest participants for the workshop and pre-approve the final list of participants to be supported under this award.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Miskito People of Honduras: Saving Themselves, Saving Their Endangered Wild Macaws

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to improve wildlife security in the Moskitia, Honduras by developing conservation capacity of governmental entities, indigenous communities, and other key stakeholders to reduce poaching of parrots. The project is intended to conserve the two most endangered parrots in Honduras, the Central American scarlet macaw and the great green macaw by addressing the impact of illegal wildlife trade. Specific activities include: (1) publication of a National Parrot Conservation Protocol and conducting workshops and trainings to authorities on how to confiscate, care for, and liberate parrots caught in illegal trade; (2) supporting an indigenous ranger patrol system to monitor and protect wild nest sites of macaws; (3) carrying out a public campaign to grow support for the species among local indigenous communities, deter illegal traffic centered in semi-urban areas, and raise national awareness of the impact and consequences of illegal wildlife trafficking; and (4) performing population monitoring at key point count locations at the end of the breeding season.

participating-org.narrative: Fundacin Investigacin en Ciencias para el Estudio y Conservacin de la Biodiversidad

title.narrative: Securing habitat in a binational linkage critical for jaguar connectivity

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support a binational conservation effort in the Sierra del Merendon transboundary region, including the Sierra Caral Reserve in Guatemala and Cusuco National Park in Honduras. The project is intended to conserve a critical jaguar corridor for regional connectivity by addressing illegal hunting and habitat incursions. Specific activities include: (1) designing a collaborative database to collect and systematize information on threats; (2) conducting patrols to detect, deter, and prosecute illegal activities; (3) conducting passive acoustic monitoring for gun hunting patterns in core areas; (4) implementing an adaptive patrol plan to mitigate habitat threats; (5) training park staff in SMART monitoring protocols and passive acoustic monitoring of gun hunting patterns; (6) strengthen community park guard groups living in the protected areas in both countries; and (7) creation of a Binational Working Group for the Conservation of Sierra del Merendon.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Reintroduccin de pecares en el Parque Nacional Jeannette Kawas: restaurando las presas del.jaguar y una especie paisaje

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support the conservation of jaguars in Jeannette Kawas National Park in Honduras through a collared peccary reintroduction effort. The project is intended to conserve a critical jaguar corridor for regional connectivity by increasing the jaguar natural prey base and reducing human-jaguar conflict. Specific activities include: (1) reintroduction of a group of collared peccaries in the park; (2) community outreach to grow community support for peccary and jaguar conservation; and (3) increased SMART patrols within the park to deter illegal activities, including poaching.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Fortalecimiento de la Gestin de Conservacin de la Reserva del Hombre y la Bisfera del Ro Pltano

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to strengthen park management in the Rio Pltano Biosphere Reserve of Honduras by supporting park guards from the national wildlife authority (ICF). This protected area, a World Heritage Site in Danger, has long suffered from instability and incursions for illegal natural resource and wildlife use. The project is intended to conserve a highly diverse array of distinct ecosystems and key species such as jaguars, Bairds tapirs, giant anteaters, West Indian Manatees, macaws, and harpy eagles by reducing threats from poaching, wildlife trafficking, and habitat destruction. Specific activities include: (1) recruitment and training of additional park rangers in operations, law enforcement monitoring tools, and forest fire management and control; (2) education and outreach activities with local communities; and (3) biological monitoring of key landscape species.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Reduction of Shark Trade in Central America through Public Engagement and Behavioral Change

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to counter wildlife trafficking in Central America by characterizing and changing public demand for threatened sharks and rays at a strategic location for the entire region: Honduras. This project is intended to conserve coastal sharks and rays, including endangered hammerhead sharks, by addressing the drivers and impacts of seasonal demand and consumption and transboundary trade, notably the role of culture and religion in underpinning the strong seasonal demand for elasmobranch meat during the Lenten Season, when sea protein consumption predominates. Specific activities will include: (1) Document the principal and secondary stakeholders, their motivations, interests and aspirations in relation to shark and ray capture, trade and consumption; (2) design, create, and launch social and behavioral communication campaign; and (3) evaluate and communicate results of the campaign, and develop framework for replication.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Empowered Miskito Women Conserving the Central American Scarlet Macaw

description.narrative: (1) training 20 Miskito women from six local villages in forest patrols, handi-crafts and as environmental educators for parrot conservation; (2) supporting an indigenous womens ranger team to monitor and protect wild nest sites of macaws closer to the villages while the men continue patrols in more remote locations; (3) led by female rangers, develop wildlife and parrot clubs with local school children as well as a community parrot festival; and (4) selection of four women with leadership potential to participate as Ambassadors for the community and parrot conservation in a national and international biodiversity conference.

title.narrative: Empowered Miskito Women Conserving the Central American Scarlet Macaw

description.narrative: The project is intended to conserve the two most endangered parrots in Honduras, the Central American scarlet macaw and the great green macaw. About 500 scarlet macaws (ara macao cyanoptera), recently listed as Endangered on the U.S. Endangered Species Act with an estimated 1,500 individuals, depend upon the Moskitias forests. Specific activities include: (1) training 20 Miskito women from six local villages in forest patrols, handi-crafts and as environmental educators for parrot conservation; (2) supporting an indigenous womens ranger team to monitor and protect wild nest sites of macaws closer to the villages while the men continue patrols in more remote locations; (3) led by female rangers, develop wildlife and parrot clubs with local school children as well as a community parrot festival; and (4) selection of four women with leadership potential to participate as Ambassadors for the community and parrot conservation in a national and international biodiversity conference.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to improve wildlife security in Jeannette Kawas National Park in Honduras by strengthening conservation capacity of governmental entities, local communities, and other key stakeholders to reduce poaching and wildlife trafficking. The project is intended to conserve iguanas, freshwater turtles, and peccaries, which indirectly increases the natural prey base of jaguars and reduces human-jaguar conflict.

title.narrative: INDIGENOUS GREAT GREEN MACAW SANCTUARY IN LA MOSKITIA, HONDURAS

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE SUPPORTING A CONSERVATION EFFORT LED BY 11 INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES IN THE REMOTE MOSKITIA REGION OF HONDURAS BY SUSTAINING PATROLS AND ESTABLISHING A BIRD SANCTUARY. THE PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED GREAT GREEN MACAW (ARA AMBIGUOUS) BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING AND HABITAT DESTRUCTION. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE (1) MEASURING THE BASELINE POPULATION OF GREAT GREEN MACAWS (GGM) AND DOCUMENTING CURRENT ACTIVE NESTS IN THE REGION TO BETTER UNDERSTAND POPULATION DYNAMICS (2) CONSTRUCTING A RANGER STATION, TRAILS, AND MONITORING KIOSK FOR MONITORING AND PATROLLING ACTIVITIES, AS WELL AS FOR ECOTOURISM AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES THAT WILL PROVIDE ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR LOCALS (3) COORDINATING WITH THE HONDURAN ARMY TO PATROL WEEKLY DURING NESTING SEASON TO DISSUADE POACHERS FROM ENTERING THE AREA (5) IN COORDINATION WITH LOCAL VILLAGES AND THE TERRITORIAL COUNCIL, DEVELOPING A GGM SANCTUARY ON PUBLIC LAND THAT WILL PROTECT GGMS AND PROVIDE A PLACE FOR EDUCATION AND ECOTOURISM AND (6) STRENGTHENING LOCAL CAPACITY TO MANAGE THE PROJECT BY PARTNERING WITH THE FOUNDATION FOR ECOSYSTEM AND BIODIVERSITY RESEARCH AND CONSERVATION TO PROMOTE PROJECT SUSTAINABILITY.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

title.narrative: INDIGENOUS GREAT GREEN MACAW SANCTUARY IN LA MOSKITIA, HONDURAS

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE SUPPORTING A CONSERVATION EFFORT LED BY 11 INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES IN THE REMOTE MOSKITIA REGION OF HONDURAS BY SUSTAINING PATROLS AND ESTABLISHING A BIRD SANCTUARY. THE PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED GREAT GREEN MACAW (ARA AMBIGUOUS) BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING AND HABITAT DESTRUCTION. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) MEASURING THE BASELINE POPULATION OF GREAT GREEN MACAWS (GGM) AND DOCUMENTING CURRENT ACTIVE NESTS IN THE REGION TO BETTER UNDERSTAND POPULATION DYNAMICS (2) CONSTRUCTING A RANGER STATION, TRAILS, AND MONITORING KIOSK FOR MONITORING AND PATROLLING ACTIVITIES, AS WELL AS FOR ECOTOURISM AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES THAT WILL PROVIDE ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR LOCALS (3) COORDINATING WITH THE HONDURAN ARMY TO PATROL WEEKLY DURING NESTING SEASON TO DISSUADE POACHERS FROM ENTERING THE AREA (5) IN COORDINATION WITH LOCAL VILLAGES AND THE TERRITORIAL COUNCIL, DEVELOPING A GGM SANCTUARY ON PUBLIC LAND THAT WILL PROTECT GGMS AND PROVIDE A PLACE FOR EDUCATION AND ECOTOURISM AND (6) STRENGTHENING LOCAL CAPACITY TO MANAGE THE PROJECT BY PARTNERING WITH THE FOUNDATION FOR ECOSYSTEM AND BIODIVERSITY RESEARCH AND CONSERVATION TO PROMOTE PROJECT SUSTAINABILITY.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
